Problem:
In a controlled experiment, the temperature \( T \) of a substance is related to its electrical resistance \( R \) through the equation \( R(T) = R_0 e^{aT} \), where \( a \) and \( R_0 \) are constants. An additional thermal experiment involves the application of a function \( g(T) = T + \Delta T \), where \( \Delta T \) is a constant temperature change.

If \( g(T) \) is applied resulting in a new temperature \( T + \Delta T \) at time \( t \), will the resistance \( R(T + \Delta T) \) at \( T \) depend only on \( a \), not on \( \Delta T \)?
Explanation: Applying \( g(T) \) modifies the temperature by adding \( \Delta T \), thereby changing the course of the resistance evolution to \( R(T + \Delta T) = R_0 e^{a(T + \Delta T)} \). Consequently, the final resistance value is influenced by both \( a \) and \( \Delta T \), signifying a dependency beyond just \( a \).
